analytic.title: Sparsity-Aware Transmit Beamspace Design for FDA-MIMO Radar

div.p: Frequency diverse array (FDA) can produce a range-angle-dependent beampattern due to the employment of a small frequency increment across the array elements. By utilizing this characteristic, this letter devises an FDA and multiple-input multiple-output hybrid radar to jointly estimate the ranges and angles of multiple targets via optimal transmit beamspace design. A uniform elemental power constraint is adopted as the optimization criterion is to minimize the mutual coherence of the sensing matrix using a sparse model and to achieve high-resolution estimation in both range and angle dimensions. A cyclic optimization approach based on power method-like is further developed to solve the non-convex design problem. The excellent performance of the proposed approach is demonstrated via computer simulations.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
Highlights
div.p: • We devise an FDA and MIMO hybrid radar to jointly estimate the ranges and angles of multiple targets via optimal transmit beamspace design.
• A uniform elemental power constraint is adopted as the optimization criterion to minimize the mutual coherence of the sensing matrix using a sparse model.
• We exploit cyclic optimization and power method-like approaches to tackle the problem.
• We employ different methods to evaluate the performance for range, angle and amplitude estimation.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Frequency diverse array (FDA), unlike a standard phased-array, can produce a range-angle-dependent beampattern by employing a small frequency increment across the array elements [1]. As a result, FDA radar is able to utilize its range-angle-dependent beampattern characteristics to jointly estimate the range and angle parameters of a target. However, FDA radar produces range and angle coupled target response [2]. Several methods have been proposed to alleviate this problem. A double-pulse FDA radar was proposed to determine the angles of targets and then their ranges [3]. In [4], we showed that the FDA elements could be divided into multiple subarrays for range and angle estimation of targets, but only a simple two-target scene is considered.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: Owing to the merits of multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) radar [5], there have been growing interests in integrating the FDA architecture into a MIMO radar system. In [6], a structure named FDA-MIMO was proposed by combining MIMO and FDA techniques. In [7], an unambiguously joint range and angle estimation method was suggested by utilizing the range-angledependent characteristic of the FDA-MIMO radar. Another FDA-MIMO radar with logarithmic frequency offset was developed in [8] for handling multiple targets with different ranges. However, in the aforementioned FDA-MIMO radar systems, high-resolution estimation demands more transmit waveforms and snapshots, which results in high signal processing complexity.

In this letter, we employ sparse model to design the transmit beamspace for the FDA-MIMO radar. The essence is under power constraint, to optimize the sensing matrix with the minimum mutual coherence criterion. However, the resultant design problem is to minimize a non-convex quartic function with respect to the weight matrix. We exploit a cyclic optimization and power method-like approach to tackle the problem. Furthermore, the Cramér-Rao lower bound (CRLB) estimation performance for the angle and range is derived. Note that the amplitude parameters are also of interest [9], [10]. In this study, we employ different methods to evaluate the performance for range, angle and amplitude estimation.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section II establishes the signal model of a FDA-MIMO radar system. Section III proposes the transmit beamspace design based on cyclic optimization and power method-like approach. Section IV provides numerical simulations to demonstrate the performance improvement due to optimal beamspace design. Finally, conclusions are drawn in Section V.

div.head: Simulation Results
div.p: Computer simulations are carried out to evaluate the range, angle and amplitude estimation performance of the proposed approach. In particular, we compare the performance between with and without the transmit beamspace optimization. Throughout this section, a uniform linear array with 12 FDA elements is chosen as the transmitter and 12 phased-array elements at the receiver are assumed. The center carrier frequency f 0 is 10 GHz, and the frequency increment ∆f =3 MHz is employed. We assume circularly symmetric independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) additive complex Gaussian noise. The signalto-noise ratio (SNR) is set to 20 dB. The FDA-MIMO radar will be scanned across an angular region ranging from -30 0 to 30 0 with a step size of 1 0 , and range region belonging to 1m to 100m with step size of 1m.

According to (12), Fig. 1 shows the histogram of the coherence coefficients associated with the steering matrix and optimized sensing matrix obtained by the proposed method. The cross correlation coefficient is defined in (12). It can be observed that the coherence values of the optimized sensing matrix are obviously smaller than those of the steering matrix. Their maximum coherence values are 0.33 and 0.98, respectively. This implies that better estimation performance is achieved for the proposed method.

To examine the target estimation performance of the transmit beamspace design method, we assume four targets located at different ranges and angles, namely, (r 1 =50m, θ 1 = 0 0 ), (r 2 =25m, θ 2 = 0 0 ), (r 3 =50m, θ 3 = -20 0 ), (r 4 =25m, θ 4 = -20 0 ), with the amplitudes β 1 = 10, β 2 = 10, β 3 = 8, β 4 = 8, respectively. Fig. 2 compares the estimation performance using several typical algorithms (MUSIC, IAA and IAA-R [10]). Note that the data are collected from only one snapshot for all algorithms and 20 iterations are adopted for the IAA and IAA-R. It is observed in Fig. 2 mit beamspace optimization (namely, only with the steering matrix ), IAA-R has significantly better resolution than MUSIC and IAA. However, the IAA-R does not provide accurate target estimation and produces multiple false targets nearby the true targets. For the TBO case, the MUSIC, IAA and IAA-R results are shown in Fig. 2(b), (d) and (f), respectively. As evidenced, the poor resolutions of MUSIC and IAA are improved by the optimized transmit beamspace. In addition, the optimized transmit beamspace also improves the IAA-R performance. Fig. 3 shows the root mean squared error (RMSE) of the range, angle, and amplitude estimation for four targets. The results are obtained through 100 independent Monte-Carlo simulations. It is seen that the TBO achieves considerable range and angle estimation performance improvement for moderate SNRs, namely, SNR ≥ -5 dB. Nevertheless, the TBO+IAA and TBO+IAA-R provide much better amplitude estimation performance than the TBO+MUSIC.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In this letter, a transmit beamspace design based on cyclic optimization and power method-like was proposed in order to improve the FDA-MIMO resolution and parameter estimation performance. Simulation results show that the mutual coherence is significantly reduced by the optimized transmit beamspace. This implies that better estimation performance can be achieved. The numerical results for several typical spatial spectral estimators show that the optimized transmit beamspace indeed achieves better estimation performance for the FDA-MIMO radar. In our future work, we will extend our approach to the off-grid scenarios to examine the target estimation performance.
